column2: School Description\rBaker Elementary School is one of three schools in the Baker Valley Unified School District
column3: the largest district\rby total area in the State of California
column4: yet one of the smallest by student enrollment. It is the only elementary\rschool in the district. Baker Elementary School is located in the Mojave Desert along Interstate 15 between\rBarstow and the California-Nevada Stateline. The school serves students in grades K through 5 and follows a\rmodified traditional calendar from early August to late May. The school staff strives to provide the students with\ra rigorous and challenging curriculum that is relevant and engaging to prepares students to face the demands\rof the 21st century workforce and college.\rMission Statement\rBaker Elementary School will provide high quality
column6: and meaningful education to all students.\rStudents will develop and apply their individual talents
column10: lifelong learners and be productive members of society.\rVision Statement\rBaker Braves will achieve personal and professional success and become responsible and productive citizens.\rStudent Enrollment by Grade LevelStudent Enrollment by Student Group\rNumber ofPercent of\rGrade Level\rStudentsStudent GroupTotal\rGrade K13Enrollment\rGrade 114Black or African American1.70%\rGrade 25American Indian or Alaska Native1.70%\rGrade 37Asian-\rGrade 47Filipino-\rGrade 512Hispanic or Latino82.80%\rTotal Enrollment58Native Hawaiian or Pacific Islander-\rWhite13.80%\rTwo or More Races-\rStudent Group\rSocioeconomically Disadvantaged96.60%\rEnglish Learners56.90%\rStudents with Disabilities8.60%\rFoster Youth-\rHomeless43.10%\r\rStudent enrollment for the 2018-19 school year was 58 students total for Baker Elementary School. This\rrepresents a slight increase in enrollment compared to recent years.\rAConditions of Learning\rState Priority: Basic\rThe SARC provides the following information relevant to the State priority: Basic (Priority 1):                     Unnamed: 0

program. Low-poverty schools are those with student eligibility of approximately 39 percent or less in the free and reduced price meals program.

column1: Year and month in which the data were collected: November 2019
All textbooks used in the core curriculum at Baker Elementary School are aligned to the California Common
Core State Standards. Standards-based instructional materials are approved by the district’s Board of
Education. The district used to follow the State Board of Education’s six-year adoption cycle for the core
content materials and the eight-year cycle for textbook adoptions in foreign language visual and performing
arts and health. The table below shows the current materials being used in the core academic subjects.

column2: District maintenance and site custodial staff ensures that the repairs necessary to keep the school in good\rcondition are completed in a timely manner. School employees communicate non-routine maintenance\rrequests by submitting work orders
column3: which are addressed in a timely manner.  Morning inspections by the\rmaintenance staff ensures that the facilities are cleared of any safety hazards before the students and teaching\rstaff arrive.\rThe school counts with three shared maintenance workers to ensure the premises are kept safe for everyone.\rThese three workers are responsible for cleaning the classrooms
column8: and trash removal. Restrooms are\rchecked regularly throughout the day for cleanliness and subsequently cleaned as needed. The principal and\rCBO meet with custodial staff daily concerning maintenance and school safety issues.\rA few years ago
column9: the district invested in a new gym floor to help increase school spirit. Maintenance of the gym\rfloor has been performed as needed to ensure students and staff enjoy the facility. LED lighting has more\rrecently been installed throughout the campus
column10: and the student restrooms have been remodeled. To improve\rcampus security
column11: cameras have been installed in various strategic locations around campus
column12: and these\rcameras are monitored constantly for suspicious or other inappropriate activity. Also
column13: a buzzer lock system has\rnow has been installed at the main entrance to the school. Currently
column14: there is work being done on roofs to\rupdate them to ensure rainwater does not sip through into the classrooms.\rSchool Facility Good Repair Status\rThe maintenance personnel use the Facility Inspection Tool (FIT) to conduct an annual inspection of the\rfacilities. The purpose of the FIT is to determine the adequacy of the school facilities to provide a safe and\rnurturing learning environment and to identify any areas that require repairs. The most recent inspection was\rconducted on January 7
column15: 2020 and the results from the inspection were satisfactory in all areas assessed. The\rareas included in the inspection are all in good condition. In previous years
column17: ” but\rthe remodeling done this year has greatly improve the facilities. The overall rating from the evaluation for the\rentire school facility was good. The following table shows the rating for each of the areas inspected in the\rreport.\rThe most recent FIT inspection was conducted on January 7

column4: either because the number of students in this category is too small for\rstatistical accuracy or to protect student privacy.\r\rCEngagement\rState Priority: Parental Involvement\rThe SARC provides the following information relevant to the State priority: Parental Involvement (Priority 3):\r●Efforts the school district makes to seek parent input in making decisions for the school district and\reach school site\rOpportunities for Parental Involvement (School Year 2018–19)\rParents are encouraged to get involved and to actively engage in their child’s educational experiences in a\rvariety of methods. Some of these opportunities for engagement include the following:\r●School Site Council. Parents are invited to become active partners in the development of their child’s\reducational program by becoming members of the School Site Council. Participation in this committee\rensures that parents have a voice in the educational program for their children.\r●District and School English Learner Advisory Council. Parents are encouraged to become\rmembers and to attend meetings of the District English Learner Advisory Council. Participation in this\rcommittee ensures that parents have an active role in any decisions that will affect the English Learner\rpopulation.\r●Workshops with the Principal and Teachers. Parents are invited to attend workshops hosted by the\rprincipal and the teachers. During the workshops
column6: teachers and the principal have\ropportunities to socialize and communicate in a more relaxed environment. The workshops also serve\ras an opportunity to solicit input from the parents pertaining to the students’ educational programs.\r●Special Event Nights. More recently the staff have been hosting special event nights to give students\ran opportunity to showcase their special abilities in the area of the arts. These events include Author’s\rNight
column8: Game Night and the Science Fair. These events give parents an opportunity to\rlearn more about what their children do in school
column9: and allow them to meet with the teachers to discuss\rany concerns.\r●Chaperoning. Parents are encouraged to chaperone various school activities and events. These\rinclude chaperoning for field trips
column11: and dances.\rState Priority: School Climate\rThe SARC provides the following information relevant to the State priority: School Climate (Priority 6):\r●Pupil suspension rates;\r●Pupil expulsion rates; and\r●Other local measures on the sense of safety  Unnamed: 0

column2: Suspensions and Expulsions\rDuring the school year 2016-17
column5: none of the students in Baker Elementary School were\rsuspended or expelled. These data very closely resemble the district averages and are significantly below the\rstate suspension and expulsion averages.\rSchoolDistrictState\rRate (Percents)\r2016-172017–18 2018–192016–17 2017–18 2018–192016-172017–18 2018–19\rSuspensions------0.80----3.603.503.50\rExpulsions------------0.100.100.10\rSchool Safety Plan (School Year 2019–20)\rBaker Elementary School’s Safety Plan is a document with information pertaining to the proper way of\rresponding in the event of an emergency or an unforeseen situation. The plan is revised and updated as\rneeded by the School Site Council once per year. The date it was last reviewed and discussed by the School\rSite Council was in October 2019.\rThe key elements included in the School Safety Plan include:\r●Organizational Roles and Responsibilities. This section details what is expected from each of the\rindividuals who respond to an emergency
column8: and first responders. It also\rcontains details about what information is released to the public and who is responsible for releasing\rthat information.\r●Functional Content. This section includes details on what the appropriate response should be of a\rvariety of specific emergencies
column15: medical and mental health and security in general.\r●Other Hazard and Threat Specific Situations. This section details the procedures in case of a hazard\ranalysis
column26: and a\rbiological hazard or blood borne pathogen.\r●Recovery and Mitigation. This section includes information on how to reduce the stress caused by an\remergency situation as well as the proper way of record keeping and cost analyses.\rThe Civil Grand Jury visited our district campus on December 5
column27: 2018.  The purpose of the visit was to\revaluate our district’s safety preparedness in the event of a natural disaster
column28: or traumatic event.  We were one\rof the districts randomly chosen throughout the county to be visited and during their visit
column29: we participated in a\rQ&A regarding safety
column30: and they toured the campus to inspect.  They were pleased to find several updated\rsafety features that have been implemented in order to better protect our students
column32: and staff.  Some of\rthe new updated safety features include Raptor
column33: an online registration system for all visitors entering the\rcampus.  We also have installed extensive cameras throughout the school grounds to monitor activity 24 hours\ra day.  Another addition in progress is additional fencing surrounding the perimeter of the campus
column35: the findings from the visit were positive and there were no recommendations at this time.\rWe conduct regular fire drills
column36: and we participate annually in the Great American Shakeout for earthquake\rpreparedness.  We are also updating our bell system to feature multiple rings categorized for specific drills.\rOur job is to create a safe environment for our children so that they can receive the best education possible.\rSafety is a key district priority and we take it very seriously.  ... column2: the number of specialized personnel is relatively low.

column1: The school counts with one part-time behavioral counselor/psychology who works with the students two days a
week and a part-time speech pathologist who sees students three days a week.
Note: Cells with N/A values do not require data.
* One Full Time Equivalent (FTE) equals one staff member working full time; one FTE could also represent two staff members who each work 50 percent
Expenditures Per Pupil and School Site Teacher Salaries (Fiscal Year 2017–18)
The expenditure per student at Baker Elementary School is 16.91% lower than that of the district as a whole
and it is 136.6% higher than the state expenditure per student. The reason for this difference is that the class
sizes in Baker Elementary School are significantly below the state average class size. Average teacher
salaries at the school are about 9% lower than the average for the district and 21% lower than the state
